skill.name: ghe-thread-manager
skill.description:
Use this skill when the user expresses ANY intent related to issue/thread management:

- Switching issues: "let's work on X", "switch to #Y", "go to the auth issue"
- Checking status: "what are we working on?", "current issue?", "status?"
- Background work: "what's in background?", "any features ready?", "check progress"
- Starting development: "implement X", "add feature", "fix bug Y", "build a..."
- Joining reviews: "let me see the review", "check that feature", "join #X"
- Pausing/resuming: "pause this", "come back later", "resume #X"
- Stopping transcription: "stop tracking", "don't record this", "private mode"
- Resuming last session: "what were we working on?", "resume last issue", "continue where we left off"
- Any natural expression of wanting to change focus or check work status

This skill interprets natural language - users should NOT memorize commands.
For the full GHE workflow protocol, see skill: github-elements-tracking

security_audit.summary: Skill provides instructions for managing GitHub issue threads and transcription states. It references external scripts that handle GitHub API calls and file operations, but contains no executable code itself. The skill is primarily documentation and workflow instructions.

medium_findings.title: Multiple external script executions referenced
medium_findings.description: The skill references numerous external Python and bash scripts that execute system commands, including auto_transcribe.py, create_feature_thread.py, check_review_ready.py. These scripts have the capability to modify GitHub issues, manage transcription states, and interact with the GitHub API. While the skill itself doesn't execute code, it provides detailed instructions for executing these external scripts which could be modified or compromised.

medium_findings.title: GitHub API access with broad permissions
medium_findings.description: The skill instructs execution of scripts that interact with GitHub API for creating issues, posting comments, and managing repository state. The gh command is used extensively with user authentication, which could potentially access private repositories, user data, and perform actions on behalf of the user.

low_findings.title: File system access for configuration
low_findings.description: The skill references accessing ~/.claude directory for plugin settings and /tmp for temporary files. It also mentions writing to .claude/last_active_issue.json for tracking session state. This is standard behavior for configuration management but represents file system access beyond the immediate project directory.

low_findings.title: Environment variable access
low_findings.description: The skill references accessing CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT environment variable and GITHUB_OWNER for GitHub API operations. This is necessary for the skill's functionality but represents environment access that could potentially expose system information.

content.user_title: Manage GitHub issue threads and transcription states
content.value_statement: Developers struggle to track conversations across multiple GitHub issues and maintain context between sessions. This skill enables natural language control over issue threads, automatic transcription management, and seamless switching between development contexts.
actual_capabilities: Switch between GitHub issues using natural language
Start and stop transcription to issues
limitations: Requires GitHub repository with proper permissions
Depends on external GHE plugin scripts
Cannot create issues without GitHub API access
Transcription state must be manually managed

use_cases.title: Multi-issue development workflow
use_cases.description: Switch between different features and bugs while maintaining conversation context in GitHub issues

use_cases.title: Track team progress across issues
use_cases.description: Monitor background development work and join review sessions when ready

use_cases.title: Collaborative issue management
use_cases.description: Participate in multiple discussions while keeping conversations organized and searchable

prompt_templates.title: Switch to an issue
prompt_templates.scenario: Start working on a specific GitHub issue
prompt_templates.prompt: Let's work on issue #42 about the login bug

prompt_templates.title: Check current status
prompt_templates.scenario: Find out what issue is currently active
prompt_templates.prompt: What issue are we working on?

prompt_templates.title: Create background thread
prompt_templates.scenario: Start development work without switching context
prompt_templates.prompt: Implement dark mode toggle for the settings page

prompt_templates.title: Resume last session
prompt_templates.scenario: Continue where you left off previously
prompt_templates.prompt: Resume the last issue we were working on

output: Transcription is now ACTIVE. Everything we discuss will be posted to Issue #42: Fix authentication bug on login page.
Say 'stop tracking' or 'go private' at any time to disable transcription.

best_practices: Always announce transcription state changes to keep users informed
Use natural language - no need to memorize specific commands
Check background thread status regularly to catch completed work
anti_patterns: Don't silently switch issues without user confirmation
Never assume users remember their current transcription state
Avoid creating issues without clear titles and descriptions

faq.question: Is this compatible with all GitHub repositories?
faq.answer: Yes, works with any GitHub repository you have access to, including private repos with proper permissions.

faq.question: What are the limits on issue creation?
faq.answer: Limited by GitHub API rate limits. Standard GitHub accounts allow 5000 requests per hour.

faq.question: How does it integrate with existing workflows?
faq.answer: Integrates seamlessly with GHE plugin ecosystem, automatically coordinating with agents and phase gates.

faq.question: Is my conversation data safe?
faq.answer: Transcription only posts to GitHub issues you explicitly select. Private conversations stay private until you choose to share.

faq.question: What if the skill can't find my issue?
faq.answer: Use exact issue numbers or descriptive search terms. The skill will ask for clarification if multiple matches are found.

faq.question: How is this different from standard GitHub CLI?
faq.answer: This skill provides natural language control and automatic transcription management, not just raw GitHub operations.
